FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

	There has been no major spill or release of formaldehyde from the facility in the last five years.
	For any incidents which occur, employees complete a non-conformance notification (NCN) or incident report to identify and correct the root cause(s) of the event.  The following list describes some of the improvements which have been made as a result of these investigations:
-Tank level alarms and gauges improvements.
- Improvement to the mechanical Integrity program by the introduction of a new software program.
- Upgraded secondary containment in tank farms.
- Improvements and additional equipment for the scrubber system.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

	The Smyrna plant maintains a written emergency response plan that is designed to protect employees, the public, and the environment.  This plan includes personnel safety, evacuation plans, and community emergency response notification procedures. The emergency response plan is coordinated with local emergency responders (e.g., the fire department).  This includes annual meetings and plant visits with community responders, so that they are aware of the hazards of the processes.   This coordination and communication ensure that the public is quickly notified, when necessary, and that action is promptly taken to minimize the consequences of a release.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS

	In-house compliance audits are performed annually to ensure that the prevention program activities at the facility are adequate and that safety issues are addressed effectively.  Audits are performed by an EHS team that is knowledgeable in the processes but is independent of our facility to ensure a thorough and complete evaluation.  The audit team systematically evaluates each aspect of the prevention program, ensuring both compliance with the RMP rule and effective hazard prevention.  The results of audits are documented, and recommendations are tracked until they are resolved. 

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

	The prevention program described previously ensures the safe operation of the facility by providing our employees with a system they can use to safely perform their job functions.  This management system helps prevent hazards associated with equipment failures and human error.  In addition to the prevention program, Compass has safety features built into the design of the facility that help to ensure safe process operation for the employees, the public and the environment.  These safety features may contain, or control a release, detect a release or reduce the consequences of a release.  They may also prevent a release by providing strict engineering design standards for process equipment.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes in our facility:
- Release detection devices, level controls.
- Procedures require a plant employee be present during loading and unloading, 
 to monitor operations.
- Valves to permit isolation of the process.
- Automated notification systems for some process parameters, (e.g., high level, high pressure).
- Manual shutdown controls located in the control room.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

	Compass encourages employees to be involved in every aspect of process safety management, risk management, and accident prevention.  Employees are routinely asked to participate in PHAs, incident investigations, management of change hazard analyses, and all other aspects of the prevention programs.  Employees have access to all information developed as part of the prevention programs and are specifically informed of any changes that occur in their process or work areas.  

SAFE WORK PRACTICES

	Compass has established safe work practices that ensure the safety of the employees.  Examples of these procedures include (1) hot work permits, designed to control spark or flame producing activities, (2) a permit and procedure to control confined space entry, and (3) a lockout/tagout procedure for isolating energy sources during maintenance.  These are some of procedures and permits ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

CONTRACTORS

	Compass Chemicals uses contractors for various activities such as maintenance and construction.  All contractors are evaluated to ensure that they are well trained and are able to perform their job function in a safe manner.  A contractors safety record and performance are reviewed during the selection process.  Once a contractor is selected, the plant provides training and procedures to ensure that contractor employees (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) are aware of the hazards associated with the area in which they will be working, (3) understand the emergency response procedures and (4) report

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

	Compass reviews any changes to the processes to determine if new hazards are being introduced, or existing prevention measures are threatened.  Except for replacements-in-kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve), all changes are subjected to a hazard analysis to ensure that (1) new hazards are not inadvertently introduced into the system, (2) safety consequences resulting from the change are addressed, (3) operators in the process are notified of the change and made aware of possible repercussions and (4) that all training material, process safety information and operating procedures are updated.  The management of change system applies to changes to the chemicals used, process equipment, technology, operating or other related procedures, and other facility changes.

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

	Whenever a change occurs that requires updating the process safety information, the Smyrna plant performs a pre-startup safety review.  This review ensures that safety features, procedures, personnel and the equipment are prepared for service, before the process is restarted.  A pre-startup safety review includes a field verification of new construction and serves a quality assurance function by verifying that accident prevention measures are implemented correctly.  Generally, a pre-startup review will ensure that (1) construction and equipment are consistent with design standards, (2) adequate operating, safety and maintenance procedures are in place, (3) training for all affected employees is completed, and (4) a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been performed, if necessary.

TRAINING

	The Smyrna plant trains workers perform their tasks to safely and effectively.  Employees who are new to a process are given basic training that includes (1) a general overview of the process, (2) the properties of the substances used in the process and their associated hazards and (3) a detailed review of the operating procedures for that process.  Once they have demonstrated their understanding of this initial training, they are paired with an experienced operator to learn their specific job functions and tasks.  After they demonstrate their competence in performing these tasks, they are allowed to work independently. 

	Through oral reviews, written tests and on-the-job demonstration, Compass ensures that the employees understand the training provided for them.   All training administer to an employee is documented, along with the means used to verify that the training is understood.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

	Compass maintains the mechanical integrity of the equipment to prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public or the environment.  the inspection and testing program helps identify equipment damage or deterioration before the equipment fails.  When a deficiency is found, maintenance personnel will correct the problem and identify a root cause(s) for the deficiency, so that future problems may be avoided.  The quality assurance system ensures that new or replacement equipment meets the strict design standards required for service in the facility.  The mechanical integrity program includes (1) inspection and testing procedures, (2) replacement equipment specifications, (3) procedures for safe work practices, (4) maintenance personnel training and (5) the required documentation.

A team comprising personnel with engineering, operations, environmental and maintenance experience systematically examines each hazard in each section of the process and identifies potential causes and a range of possible consequences.  The team then compares the hazard to the existing set of prevention and mitigation measures designed to contain that hazard, making further recommendations when deemed necessary.  These recommendations are listed as action items and are resolved and prioritized by management and the items are tracked until they are implemented.  Compass updates and re-validates each PHA every five years or whenever a significant change is made.  The results and findings from these re-validation studies are documented and retained and recommendations are tracked as action items by management until resolved or completed.

OPERATING PROCEDURES

	Compass engineers, operators and supervisors work together to develop and maintain operating procedures that ensure the safe operation of the facility.  These procedures cover all modes of operation, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown and (6) initial start-up of a new or improved processes.  Operating procedures are used for each process and are also used as a reference by experienced employees, to provide a consistent basis for training new employees.  In addition to describing the steps for safely conducting operations, the procedures also contain valuable information about the safe upper and lower limits, consequences of deviations and applicable safety and health information. There are operating procedures for activities involving hazardous chemicals, other than making the batches.
	 Compass manufactures using a batch sheet system which includes the operating instructions.  The batch sheets are the detailed operating procedures for making each product.

RMATION

	Compass Chemical International maintains a variety of technical documents that describe the chemicals and processes at the facility.  These documents are kept up to date and are available to all employees and address important process parameters such as (1) operating limits for the equipment, (2) design basis and configuration of the equipment and (3) physical properties and hazards associated with each chemical.  
	
	Chemical information is usually documented within the finished product manufacturing batch sheet which incorporates by reference the raw material Safety Data Sheets (SDS). SDS contain information concerning both the physical properties and the hazards associated with each chemical.  This information typically includes (1) toxicity information, (2) physical data, (3) reactivity and corrosivity data, (4) thermal and chemical stability data and (5) hazards of mixing substances together. SDS are available to all employees as well as emergency responders in the community.  SDS for all Smyrna chemicals are maintained on site. Manufacturing instructions described on the product batch sheet are followed to ensure the finished product is made safely and meets strict quality criteria.

	Important process parameters are also documented and maintained.  Engineering design documents may include (1) operating limits, (2) block flow or simplified process flow diagrams, (3) process chemistry, (4) maximum intended inventories, (5) design basis and configuration, (6) piping and instrumentation diagrams and (7) other information that is important for understanding the design intent, operating limits and hazards of each process.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSES

	The Smyrna plant has a comprehensive program for ensuring that the hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled.  Each process is examined in detail to ensure that all hazards are identified and that appropriate controls are in place to manage those hazards.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

	Compass Chemical International manufactures phosphonates, polymeric dispersants and toll manufactures products for other companies.  Raw materials are received via tank trucks, tote bins, bags, and drums.  As a part of the phosphonate manufacturing processes, Compass uses 37% formaldehyde which is covered by the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule (40 CFR 68).  The plant also implemented a combination of good design practices, an accidental release prevention program and an emergency response program to ensure the safety of the employees, the public and the environment.  Compass is committed to operating the facility in a safe and responsible manner.  Following is a brief description of the facility and the RMP regulated chemicals at the site.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
	Compass Chemical takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals.  Compass' Management System addresses each of the key features of a successful prevention program, as described in the sections below.

PROCESS SAFETY INFO

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Compass Chemical International is committed to worker and public safety and to the protection of the environment.  Compass is committed to operating and maintaining the processes in a safe and responsible manner, as demonstrated by the resources we invest to prevent accidents.  In addition to ensuring that employees have the best training in the operation of our processes, we demand that safety be the priority in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes.

It is the policy of Compass Chemical International to manufacture and distribute materials with minimal impact on the environment and without injury to the employees, customers, and community.  To that end, Compass Chemical International is committed to:
The protection of the health, safety, and security of the company employees and facilities,
Complying with all applicable federal, state and local Environmental, Health, Safety, and Security regulations and other related voluntary requirements. 
Continual reduction of the impact of our operations on the environment through ongoing pollution prevention programs.
Continual communications and openness with stakeholders.
Training all employees regarding the importance of EHS&S protection and roles they play as stewards.

Compass has implemented maintenance and inspection programs that help ensure site integrity.  The company policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  Examples of controls to prevent releases include (1) installation of pressure relief valves to prevent rupture of vessels due to over pressurization, (2) routine visual inspections and thickness checks to ensure vessels and piping are in good condition, (3) using materials of construction that are compatible with the process chemistry, (4) vessel pressures and temperatures are continuously monitored and (5) use of scrubbers to remove all emissions.
